Dialogue: Damnation!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Sorry.

Dialogue: Father, I saw a post rider at the house.

Dialogue: Thank you.  Did you finish the upper field?

Dialogue: Those swimming breaks cut into the day, don't they?

Dialogue: Thank you.  How's the spotted one's milk?

Dialogue: ... and they bundled half... almost no trace of the boys you knew...

Speaker: marion

Dialogue: Your children.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I smell turnips...

Dialogue: Father, Samuel broke the blue plate...

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: I did not...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Dinner...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: News of Boston, father?

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: I hate turnips...

Dialogue: William knocked it right out of my hands...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father...?

Speaker: marion

Dialogue: The Assembly has been reconvened, I've been called to...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Charleston!

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: We're going to Charleston!

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: When, father, when?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We'll leave tomorrow...

Speaker: the children
Dialogue: Charleston!  We're going to Charleston!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I love turnips...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: ... now count five finger lengths up from the front two stars of the Big Dipper, and that's the North Star, that's her.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: It helps her to know Mother's there.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: The New York and Rhode Island assemblies have been dissolved...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: The middle colonies?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Rioting both sides of the bay, in Chestertown they burned the Customs House and tar-and-feathered the Customs Agent.  He died of burns. In Wilmington they killed a Royal Magistrate and two Redcoats.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Anything about the convention in Philadelphia?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Poor Richard says they'll make a Declaration of Independence by July.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Scott Higgins joined the militia.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: He's seventeen.  A year younger than I.

Speaker: the children
Dialogue: Aunt Charlotte!  Aunt Charlotte!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Welcome!  Welcome!  Margaret, William, look at you...!  They're huge.  What have you been feeding them?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: They're from good stock on their mother's side.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Come, come, inside, wait until you see what I have...

Speaker: the children
Dialogue: Presents!  For me?  What do you have?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Inside, inside...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You look well, Charlotte.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: As do you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Inside, all of you...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Very well.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Look!  There's Gabriel!

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Children, inside!  All of you! Right now.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: What news?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: The British army is barricaded in Boston.  Harry Lee, is here from Virginia, recruiting for a Continental Army.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Is that why the Assembly was convened?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Yes.  He seeks a levy of troops and money.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And the Governor?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: He vowed that if the Assembly votes a single shilling to Lee, he'll dissolve the body.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Which would force our delegates in Philadelphia to vote for independence.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: And send us to war alongside Massachusetts.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Our governor is a bigger fool than I thought.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Lee is counting on your vote and expects you to be the first to enlist.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: ORDER!  ORDER!

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Our first order of business...

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: And out last if we vote a levy...

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: ORDER!  ORDER!  Mr. Simms, you do not have the floor.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Our first order of business is an address by Colonel Harry Lee of the Continental Army.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: You all know why I am here.  I am not an orator and I will not try to convince you of the worthiness of our cause.  I am a soldier and we are at war and with the declaration of independence we all expect from Philadelphia, it will soon be a formal state of war.  In preparation for that, eight of the thirteen colonies have levied money in support of a Continental Army.  I ask South Carolina to be the ninth.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Colonel Lee, Massachusetts may be at war, along with New Hampshire and Rhode Island and Virginia, but South Carolina is not at war.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Massachusetts and New Hampshire are not as far from South Carolina as you might think and the war they're fighting is not for independence of one or two colonies.  It's for the independence of a nation.

Speaker: withington
Dialogue: And what nation is that?

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: An American nation.  Colonel Lee, with your permission?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: Those of us who call ourselves Patriots are not seeking to give birth to an American nation, but to protect one that already exists.  It was born a hundred-and-seventy years ago at Jamestown, Virginia and has grown stronger and more mature with every generation reared and with every crop sown and harvested.  We are a nation and our rights as citizens of that nation are threatened by a tyrant three thousand miles away.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Thank you.  Were I an orator, those are the exact words I would have spoken.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Mister Robinson, tell me, why should I trade one tyrant, three thousand miles away, for three thousand tyrants, one mile away?

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: An elected legislature can trample a man's rights just as easily as a King can.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Captain Marion, I understood you to be a Patriot.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's Mister Marion.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I understood him to be a Patriot as well.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: If you mean by a Patriot, am I angry at the Townsend Acts and the Stamp Act?  Then I'm a Patriot.  And what of the Navigation Act?  Should I be permitted to sell my tobacco to the French traders on Martinique?  Yes, and it's an intrusion into my affairs that I can't... legally.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And what of the greedy, self-serving bastards who sit as Magistrates on the Admiralty Court and have fined nearly every man in this room. Should they be boxed about the ears and thrown onto the first ship back to England?  I'll do it myself.  And do I believe that the American colonies should stand as a separate, independent nation, free from the reins of King and Parliament?  I do, and if that makes a Patriot, then I'm a Patriot.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: But if you're asking whether I'm willing to go to war with England, the answer is, no.  I've been to war and I have no desire to do so again.

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: This from the same Captain Francis Marion whose anger was so famous during the Wilderness Campaign.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I was intemperate in my youth.  My departed wife, God bless her soul, dampened that intemperance with the mantle of responsibility.

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: Temperance can be a convenient disguise for fear.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Mister Robinson, I fought with Captain Marion in the French and Indian War, including the Wilderness Campaign.  We served as scouts under Washington and I have no doubts about Captain Marion's courage or competence on a battlefield. There's not a man in this room, or anywhere, for that matter, to whom I would more willingly trust my life.

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: I stand corrected.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Nonetheless, I would like to know, Mister Marion, how... how... how...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Damn it, Francis!  How in God's name do you expect to gain independence without going to war?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Harry, Harry, Harry...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: My hairy arse!  You live in a cave if you think we'll get independence without war...

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Gentlemen!  Please!  This is not a tavern!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Wasn't it a Union Jack we fought under?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: A long time ago...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thirteen years...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: That's a damn long time...

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Gentlemen!  Please!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You were an Englishman then...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I was an American, I just didn't know it yet...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We don't have to go to war to gain independence...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Balderdash!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: There are a thousand avenues, other than war, at our disposal...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Name five hundred.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Royal petition, delegates to court, judicial redress, economic boycott, bribery...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: That's five, keep going...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: ... time, royal succession, regicide, bribery...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: You said bribery twice...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We do not have to go to war to gain independence.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Francis, I was at Bunker Hill.  It was as bad as anything you and I saw on the frontier.  Worse than the slaughter at the Ashuelot River. The British advanced three times and we killed over seven hundred of them at point blank range.  And still, they advanced and they took the ground.  That is the measure of their resolve.  If your principles dictate independence, then war is the only way.  It has come to that.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I have seven children.  My wife is dead.  Who's to care for them if I go to war?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Wars are not fought only by childless men.  A man must weigh his personal responsibilities against his principles.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: That's what I'm doing.  I will not fight and because I won't, I will not cast a vote that will send others to fight in my stead.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: And your principles?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'm a parent, I don't have the luxury of principles.

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: Mister Speaker, I call for a vote on a levy to the Continental Army.

Speaker: hamill
Dialogue: Second.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: So moved.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Mr. Robinson.

Speaker: robinson
Dialogue: Yea.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Mr. Hamill.

Speaker: hamill
Dialogue: Yea.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Mr. Johnson.

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: Yea.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Mr. Simms.

Speaker: simms
Dialogue: Nay.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Mr. Marion.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Mr. Marion.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Nay.

Speaker: page boy
Dialogue: Twenty-eight to twelve, the levy passed!

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, I've lost respect for you. I thought you were a man of principle.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: When you have children, I hope you'll understand.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: When I have children, I hope I don't hide behind them.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Do you intend to enlist without my permission?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: One of yours?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Gabriel.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I recognize him now.  Is he as imprudent as his father was at his age?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No, thank the Lord.  He's more like his mother.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I'll see to it that he serves under me.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Not yet, Thomas.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Seventeen.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: But it's already been two years and that's two more years.  The war could be over by then.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: God willing.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Alright.  Seventeen.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Is it going to rain?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: That's not thunder.

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: Father?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Six-pounders.  Lots of them.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: How far away?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Four, five miles.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: Waxhaus?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Just east of it.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Are we safe here?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Don't worry.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: We could go stay at Aunt Charlotte's farm.  She's to the west.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No, there'll be skirmishers on the roads.  We're safer here.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Put those away.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: But father, they might come this way.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Put them away.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Enough.  I'll be in the workshop. Samuel, the cows.  Thomas, attend to your studies here on the porch. Nathan, on the back porch.  If you see anyone, come get me.  Margaret, please keep William close to you. No one is to go past the yard wall.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Children.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Samuel...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Samuel, get up to the house.  You heard father...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Up to the house, now.  All of you, come on.  Now.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: They're going to come.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Quiet.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: We're going to have to fight them off.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Father will do that.

Speaker: samuel
Dialogue: They'll probably kill us men and do Lord knows what to you women.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Samuel!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Gabriel!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: You're hurt.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: The battle, were you there?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Margaret, get bandages and water. Thomas, the porch, eyes open.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Have you seen any Redcoats?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Not yet.  What happened?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: It wasn't like Saratoga.  There, we stayed in the trees, but this time Gates marched us straight at the Redcoats.  They fired two volleys into us and we broke like straw.  I was given these dispatches... I saw Virginia Regulars surrender... as they laid down their weapons the British Green Dragoons rode into them and hacked them to bits... killed them all, over two hundred men.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: They had surrendered?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I have to get these dispatches to Hillsboro.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You're in no condition to ride.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I have no choice, I...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Margaret, take William and Susan down to the root cellar.  Thomas, go to the back porch.  Nathan and Samuel, the side windows.  Keep out of sight.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: He's dead...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thomas, help me turn him over...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thomas!

Speaker: continental sergeant
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Sergeant, there are seventeen wounded men here.  Seven Redcoats and ten Patriots, counting my son inside.  That puts me in a difficult position.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You three are the least severely wounded.  I have to ask you to leave and find care elsewhere.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Come on, boys.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Father?

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: But they're wounded.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: There are rules, even in war.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: After the Battle of Ashuelot River, against the French, I got this and the one on my leg.  I couldn't walk. Washington had to march north.  He left me with other wounded men and a like number of French prisoners. Nine for nine.  When the French found us, their surgeon gave me the best of care.  We'll be safe this way.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Your best chance is in Bennington, seven miles east, along the river road.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: You're surrendering.

Speaker: continental sergeant
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: What unit?

Speaker: continental sergeant
Dialogue: First Virginia Regulars under Colonel Hamilton.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Who cared for your wounds?

Speaker: continental sergeant
Dialogue: We did.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: With a lace table cloth?

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Kill them.

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: These men are of my regiment.  Thank you.

Speaker: redcoat
Dialogue: Rebel dispatches, sir.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I carried those.  I was wounded, these people gave me care, they have nothing to do with the dispatches.

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Lieutenant, have a detachment take our wounded to our surgeons at Camden crossing.  Use whatever horses and wagons you can find here.

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: We found this, sir.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Who carried this?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Take this one to Camden, he's a spy. He will be hung.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Colonel, he's a dispatch rider and that's a marked dispatch case.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Fire the house and barns.

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Colonel...

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: And the Rebel wounded?

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Kill them.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: A dispatch rider with a marked case cannot be held for spying.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: We're not going to hold him, we're going to hang him.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: But...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father...

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Oh, he's your son.  You should have taught him about loyalty.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Colonel, I beg you, please reconsider.  By the rules of war, a dispatch rider with a marked case...

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Would you like a lesson in the rules of war?

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Perhaps your children would.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No lesson is necessary.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Father, do something.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Gabriel!  Run!

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Major.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Thomas, please, Thomas...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Lieutenant, please...

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: I have my orders.  Sergeant!

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: Papa, look what they did to Thomas...

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: Father, they're going to take Gabriel...

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: Father, you can't let them take him...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Quiet.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Don't move.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Nathan, Samuel...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Margaret, take William and Susan to the river shed.  Hide there.  If we're not back by dawn, go up the river to the Richardson's house. They'll take you to your Aunt Charlotte's farm.  Nathan, Samuel, and I are going to get Gabriel.

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: But what about Thomas?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Leave him.  Take care of William and Susan.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Nathan, there.  Samuel, there.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'll fire first.  Then, Nathan, kill whoever is standing closest to Gabriel.  Samuel, kill the last man in the line.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: After that, Samuel, load for Nathan. If something happens to me, put down your weapons and run as fast as you can, that way, downhill.  Hide in the brush by the river, then make your way home, get the others and go to Aunt Charlotte's farm.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Boys... steady.

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: FORM BY TWOS!  BACK-TO-BACK LINES...

Speaker: redcoat corporal
Dialogue: READY...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Samuel, reload.  Nathan, untie Gabriel.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: There, there... he's alright... he's with your mother now...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Lord, we pray that You accept this child, Thomas Marion and give him a place at Your side with his mother. We ask that You embrace him and help us to understand the manner in which Your mercy works.  This we ask, in Your name.  Amen.

Speaker: marion's children
Dialogue: Amen.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: The Morgans, the Halseys, Williams, Stantons...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, it's safe.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Sleep, now.

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: Father... I killed those men...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Don't blame yourself, you did what I told you to do.

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: I'm glad I killed them... I'm glad...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Try to get some sleep.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I'll stay with them.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: How are they?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Gates is at Hillsboro with the Continental Army.  I'll leave in the morning to join him.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I'll tend my horse.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: They're asleep.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: How did this... how did I let this happen?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: You couldn't have known.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I should have known... once I would have... I used to be wary... and today I watched my son killed before my eyes... your sister civilized me and I damn myself for having let her...

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Thomas is dead but you've done nothing for which you should be ashamed.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I've done nothing and for that I am ashamed.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: If you go, I'll care for them as if they were my own.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'll leave in the morning with Gabriel.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: When will you be back?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I don't know, William.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Tomorrow?

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: No, not tomorrow.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Goodbye?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Just one word?  Goodbye?  That's all I want.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Goodbye.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No, it's too late.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Command posts... Patriot... British...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Break for the trees... break for the trees...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Send them to cover!  Goddamn you!

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, we have to do something...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's already over.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Damn you, Sergeant, don't move the wounded twice, put them straight on the wagons from the surgeons.

Speaker: patriot sergeant
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Lieutenant, detail men for outriders.  We move out as soon as the wounded are ready.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Green Dragoons came to my home, killed my son, Thomas.  It was Tarleton himself.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'm sorry I wasn't here for this.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: There's nothing you could have done, Gates is a damned fool.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We saw.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I begged him to stay in the cover of the trees but he insisted the only way to break Cornwallis was muzzle- to-muzzle.  He spent too many years in the British army.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Where is he now?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Last anyone saw, riding hard, northeast, his staff a hundred yards behind, trying to catch up.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Who's in command?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I am, I think.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: What are my orders?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: If you want orders, I've got some for you.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: We're a breath away from losing this war.  In the North, Washington is reeling from Valley Forge, running and hiding from Clinton and twelve thousand Redcoats.  Here in the South, Cornwallis has broken our back.  He captured over five thousand of our troops when he took Charleston and today he destroyed the only army that stood between him and New York.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: So now Cornwallis will head north, link up with Clinton and finish off Washington.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: And Patriots will start dying on the gallows instead of the battlefield.  Unless we can keep Cornwallis in the South until the French arrive.  A treaty was signed at Versailles after our victory at Saratoga.  The French are sending a fleet and ten thousand troops.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Fall, six months at the earliest.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Long time.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: The bigger problem is where, not when.  The French fleet won't sail north of the Chesapeake for fear of early storms.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: So you're going to try to keep Cornwallis in the South until then.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Not me, you.  I'm going north with every Continental regular I can find to reinforce Washington or he won't last six weeks.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You expect Cornwallis to be held here by militia?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Not held, just slowed down.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: They're nothing but farmers and you're asking them to try to keep a tiger in their backyard.  They'd be better off letting it move on.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: They'd be better off, but the cause wouldn't be.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: How many men does Cornwallis have under his command?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Four thousand infantry and around six hundred cavalry...  ... including the Green Dragoons under Tarleton.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'll do what I can.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I'm giving you a field commission as a colonel.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Colonel Lee, I request a transfer to Colonel Marion's command.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Granted.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Good luck.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: What now, sir?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We put out the word.  We'll start along the south side of the Santee...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: We'd cover more ground if we split up.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's safer if we stay together.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Colonel, I didn't request this transfer because you're my father. I requested it because I believe in this cause and this is where I can do the most good.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I've been doing this for two years. I'm the best scout in the Continental Army, the best horseman, the best shot, the best scavenger and I know every deer path and swamp trail between here and Charleston.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Is that so?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Yes, sir.  My father taught me.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Did your father teach you humility?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: He tried.  It didn't take.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Alright, Corporal, you take Bennington, Harrisville, Acworth and the farms along Black Swamp.  I'll take the north side of the river. We'll meet at Snow's Island.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And, Corporal...  ... be careful.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Yes...  ... father.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'm looking for John Billings.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: He's dead.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: If he comes back from the dead, tell him Francis Marion is looking for him.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: I'll be sure to do that.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'll wait.  Miracles happen.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: You expect to hold Cornwallis with militia?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I expect to try.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Trust you and Harry Lee.  Remember that damned overland you two thought up in '62 to hit Fort Louis?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It worked.  How many men can you raise?

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Not many.  Dalton, Scott, they've got their reasons; Rev. Oliver, he believes in the cause; some of the young bucks; a few like me with nothing to lose...  What about you?  You've got a lot to lose.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You coming, or not?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, this war is about more than Thomas.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: If you're here only for revenge, you're doing a disservice to him as well as yourself.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: How old are you?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You know how old I am.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: God help us all when you're forty.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Reverend.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Dalton.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You all have your own reasons for being here.  I lost a son and I intend to kill the man who killed him...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: ... But I don't consider that man's life adequate payment for the life of my son, and killing him won't keep the sons of other men from dying...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Cornwallis has to move north.  We have to keep him right here.  If he's south of the Chesapeake when the French arrive, if the French arrive, we have a chance of winning this war.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Eat, get some rest, we move out in two hours.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Gentlemen.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Major, this is not an adequate map.

Speaker: major huntington
Dialogue: We have better coming on the trailing supply convoy from Charleston.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: A useful place for our maps.

Speaker: major huntington
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir, it won't happen again.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: My harrier.  Join us, Colonel.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Gentlemen, celebration is premature. We have a difficult campaign ahead of us.  We are in predominately hostile country and we cannot rely on forage.  As we move north, the bulk of our supplies will reach us by sea, through Charleston, which will give us a long and vulnerable supply line, one that can only be secured if the locals are loyal to the crown.

Speaker: cornwallis' officers
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Nonetheless, we must remember that this is a civil war...

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: These colonials are our brethren and when this conflict is over, we will be reestablishing commerce with them.  Surrendering troops will be given quarter and unwarranted assaults on civilians will cease.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: I expect this war to be fought in a vigorous but civilized manner.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Have I made myself clear, gentlemen?

Speaker: officers
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: I believe he was speaking to us, Colonel.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Did you know that Lord Cornwallis' father was a tenant on the estate of my grandfather?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Less than a mile.  Forty-one wagons, a company of Redcoat infantry, horses at the rear.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Flanking riders?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I didn't see any.

Speaker: redcoat lieutenant
Dialogue: Across the river!  Covering fire! Double rank!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Epaulets first... Kill the officers.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: THE WAGONS!

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: We have enough arms for an army. Now all we need is an army.

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Reamer, boring tool...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Swage, broach, etching tool...

Speaker: fielding
Dialogue: A rolling gunsmith's shop...

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: We can rifle those musket barrels...

Speaker: fielding
Dialogue: Get another hundred yards out of 'em...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We'll need a forge...

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Easy enough...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We've got clay to make a chamber...

Speaker: fielding
Dialogue: Oak to make charcoal...

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Oil cloth and barrel staves to make a bellows...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And we can yank a wagon wheel, weight it, rig a piston and drive shaft and we'll have a flywheel to power the bellows...

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: That's why he's a colonel.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Shoot them!  Shoot the damn things!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Put that pistol down!

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: They followed us from the bridge. They won't let anyone near the wagon.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Stay... stay... stay...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Don't you growl at me!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Now let's see what's in this wagon.

Speaker: abner
Dialogue: Rum, French Champagne, Madeira, Port...

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: No wonder they were guarding it.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: These four wagons must be his.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: And the dogs, too, I'll wager.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: I say we drink the wine, shoot the dogs, and use the papers for musket wadding.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: His journals, letters, maps, books...

Speaker: abner
Dialogue: Colonel, we got a wagon full of officer's uniforms and more powder and muskets here.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Today was hard earned but a good start.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: In the future wounded British soldiers will be given quarters.

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: Like they gave quarter to my family? My wife and three children were hiding in our root cellar when they came.  The Redcoats locked the door and torched the house.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You have my sympathy... but the order stands.

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: And who are you to give an order like that?  We all know what you did after Fort Wilderness.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'm your commanding officer.  This is militia, not regular army.  I can't hold you here, but as long as you stay, you'll follow my orders.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Don't depend on my decency.  I'm one of that sort.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Am I one of that sort?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You're the worst of that sort. You're the sort that gives that sort a bad name.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'm going to check the watch.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: He shouldn't make light.  That Redcoat should not have been killed.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: He's not making light.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: You don't know him very well, do you?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: He's my father.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I know him well enough?

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Don't fault him for having grown up on the frontier.  It was a harder time and a harder place than you know.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I've just been inside the mind of a genius.  Lord Cornwallis knows more about war than I could in a dozen lifetimes.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Cheerful news to greet the morn.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: His victories at Charleston and Camden were perfect, strategically, tactically, logistically.  But he has a weakness.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Lord Cornwallis is brilliant.  His weakness is that he knows it.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Pride is his weakness.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Personally, I'd prefer stupidity.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Pride will do.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Why am I here, Colonel Halbert?

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: For the ball, sir?

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Why, after six weeks, are we still here to attend a ball.  By now, we should be attending balls in North Carolina, not South Carolina.

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: Our supply line, sir?

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Excellent guess, Major.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: And what, praytell, is this?

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Uh... I borrowed it from Colonel North.  I took it in at the back, added wider epaulets, a court sash and looped gold braiding on the cuffs...

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: It's a horse blanket.  First my personal baggage, then half the bridges and ferries between here and Charleston burned, a dozen convoys attacked.  Colonel, if you can't secure our supply line against militia, how do you expect to do so against Colonial regulars or the French when they come?

Speaker: colonel halbert
Dialogue: Sir, they're not like regulars, we can't find them and we don't know when or where they're going to strike.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: How impolite.  And who leads these clever, secretive fellows?

Speaker: colonel halbert
Dialogue: We don't know, sir.  He's called, the Commander by some, the Swamp Fox by others.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Colonel, I'm a civilized man but I'm finding to difficult to remain civil.  Secure my supply line.

Speaker: colonel halbert
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: redcoat guard
Dialogue: Hey, what you got there?

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: We got our own little party...

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: To hell with the officers and their fancy dress ball...

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Give us a nip, here.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Fine animals, a gift from His Majesty.  Dead now, for all I know.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Yes, we have learned.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: It's the weight of command and the lot of a widower -- memories, loneliness...  ... and long gazes at the moon.

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: Good God!

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Colonel Tarleton, you deal with these damned rebels.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: ... four baskets of apples, salt pork, sweet potatoes, jerky, hard tack, salt and powder.  It's not much, but I'll get you more.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We can't pay for this...

Speaker: green
Dialogue: I'll give you what I can, when I can.  You pay me what you can.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Francis, you remember my daughter, Anne.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Nice to see you again, Anne.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I know who you are, Gabriel Marion. The last time I saw you, I was nine and you put ink in my tea.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I... uh... that wasn't me, it was Samuel... I mean Nathan...

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: It was you and it turned my teeth black for a month.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: He's sorry.  Come.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: ... and your terms of enlistment will be month-to-month.  Every thirty days you can re-enlist or return to your families.

Speaker: reed
Dialogue: I'm in.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Talk to Abner and Scott about provisions, powder and mounts.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Twenty men here, seventeen in New Brighton, a dozen along the Black River.  We'll pass three hundred by week's end if this keeps up.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: If I'd known you were going to look like this, I never would have put ink in your tea.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: You call that a compliment?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: It's a start.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: They look nice.  As white as can be.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: He reminds me of you before you got old and ugly.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No, he takes after his mother...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: ... the younger ones barely remember her but Gabriel spent more time with Elizabeth... she taught him well, guided him, she was his North Star and mine... her father was a minister, in Boston, did you know that?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: ... Gabriel's already a better man than I could ever hope to be...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: What do you mean, old and ugly?

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: You got me beat on both accounts.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: The hell I do.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Gabriel?  Are you asleep?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: We're low on salt.  I should go to Pembroke and get some.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: You got salt last week.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Oh, right.  Baking powder, we need baking powder.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: We've got plenty of baking powder. You went to Pembroke and got five pounds two weeks ago.

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: Halt.  Look alive, boys.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Sergeant, this road is closed. Those wagons now belong to the Continental Army.

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: Ready arms!  By twos!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Sergeant, there's no reason for you and your men to die.  Just leave the wagons and go.

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: Steady, boys...

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: This is the King's highway and I advise you and your men to make way.  Prepare to fire.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's a trap...

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: FIRE!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: GO!

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Which way?

Speaker: gaskins
Dialogue: This way... no this... I think...

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: HALT!

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Enough of this.  There are other ways to run down a fox.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, no...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: That's him.  Tarleton.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Damn you!  Let go!

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, please...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Fourteen dead, eleven wounded, eighteen captured.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I should have killed him when I had the chance?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: When was that?  In the swamp at the expense of your men?  Or when he killed Thomas at the expense of your family?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Or perhaps tomorrow at the expense of our cause.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: There will be a time and a place for revenge but killing Tarleton at the expense of your duty serves no one but yourself.  Stay the course.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Stay the course... your mother used to say that to me when I'd get drunk or lose my temper.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: She'd say it to me when I picked on Thomas or Nathan.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You learned her lessons better than I.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: She got me at a more impressionable age.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Next time we'll bring more blankets.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: That would be nice.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Maybe we'll be lucky this winter and have just rain, no snow.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: That would be nice, too.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Just because the French didn't come this fall, doesn't mean they're never going to come.

Speaker: rollins
Dialogue: They're to be hung!

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: But they're prisoners-of-war!

Speaker: redcoat sentry
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: General, a message from the commander of the rebel militia.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: It seems our Swamp Fox wants to have a formal parley.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Are you going to meet with him?

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Most certainly.  Arrange it.

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: Lord Cornwallis will be with you presently.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: You may, of course, keep your weapons, but I must warn you that...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'm familiar with appropriate behavior at a military parley.

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: Yes, quite, but you should know that...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: That will be all, Major.  I'll wait for Lord Cornwallis.

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: Yes... you will wait.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: One other thing.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: The proper form of address to a superior officer, even one of an opposing army, is "Yes, sir."

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Jupiter!  Mars!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Go.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: My boys... my boys... you seem to have been well fed.  Thank you for that, Colonel.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: My pleasure, sir.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Please forgive me for keeping you waiting.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Apology accepted.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Thank you, Colonel... I'm afraid I don't know your name.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Colonel will do.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: As you wish.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Colonel... Colonel Banastre Tarleton.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Colonel.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Shall we proceed?

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Let us.  Unless you object, I would like to deem this meeting a formal negotiation and, as such, there are certain customary practices. Perhaps I could explain them to you...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'm familiar with how a formal negotiation is handled.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I served in His Majesty's army in the French and Indian War.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Oh.  Very well, then.  Would you, as the initiating party, like to begin?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Unless you would like to claim aggrieved status.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: You are familiar with how these things are done.  In fact, I would like to claim aggrieved status.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Very well, proceed, sir.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: First, you have in your possession certain belongings of mine, including clothing, private papers, furniture and personal effects of a non-military nature which I would like to have returned to me.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I will do so as soon as possible.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Please accept my apology for not having done so sooner.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Apology accepted.  Now, on the matter of the specific targeting of officers during engagements, this is absolutely unacceptable.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: That one is a bit more difficult.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Certainly you must know that in civilized warfare, officers in the field must not be accorded inappropriate levels of hostile attention.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And what are inappropriate levels of hostile attention?

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Colonel, imagine the utter chaos that would result from un-led armies having at each other.  There must be gentlemen in command to lead and, when appropriate, restrain their men.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Restrain them from the targeting of civilians, including women and children?

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: That is a separate issue.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I consider them linked.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: I beg to differ.  One is a command decision on your part.  The other represents nothing more than the occasional over-exuberance of field officers attempting to carry out their duty in difficult circumstances.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: As long as your soldiers attack civilians, I will order the shooting of your officers at the outset of every engagement.  And my men are excellent marksmen.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Very well, let us move on to...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Prisoner exchange.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You have eighteen of my men.  I want them back.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: I do have eighteen criminals under sentence of death, but I hold no prisoners-of-war.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: If that's your position, then eighteen of your officers will die. Nineteen, if you hang me with my men.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: What officers?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: In the clearing, just down from the crest, to the left of the dark pines...

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Their names, ranks and posts?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: They refused to give me their names. Their ranks are nine lieutenants, five captains, three majors and one fat colonel who called me a cheeky fellow.  Their posts?  We picked them up here-and-there last night.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: You are not a gentleman.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: If your conduct is the measure of a gentleman, I take that as a compliment.  Get my men.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Arrange the exchange.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thank you, General.  I'm sure your officers will thank you, as well.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You don't remember me, do you?

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Ah, yes, that boy.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Ugly business, doing one's duty.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Yes, ugly business.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: If you are alive when this war is over, I'm going to kill you.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Jupiter!  Mars!

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Take a detachment and go get our officers.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: This fox believes himself clever. We shall see.

Speaker: gaskins
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: No one's been here for months.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: But now we have a name for our Colonel... Francis Marion.  And with a name will come a family.

Speaker: captain morrow
Dialogue: UPSTAIRS!

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: They can't be far.  Check the outbuildings and the woods.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: It's all set.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: This will do fine.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: So he's the one they talk about, the Swamp Fox.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I thought it might be him, the bits and pieces we heard, a veteran, fought in the French and Indian War, knows the swamps.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: They won't stop looking for you and the children.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: We'll be alright, here, for now.  How is he?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I don't know... I'm his son.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: These are for you and the children.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Why didn't father come?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Speaking for months now.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Why didn't he come?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: He wanted to, Susan, but he couldn't leave his men.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: He left us.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I know he did and he's sorry.  He'll come back as soon as he can.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: There are some letters here from him.  Some are just to you.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I don't care.  I hate him.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You don't hate him.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Yes, I do.  I hate him and I hope he never comes back.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: She spoke?  Susan spoke?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Full sentences.  As if she had been speaking all along.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I don't believe it... and I wasn't there for it...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Tell me everything she said, word for word.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: She said... she loves you and misses you but she understands why you can't be there with her.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: She said that?  Oh, my Lord, she said that?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Isn't that something.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, there's something else I need to talk to you about.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Come with me.  I'll tell you when we get there.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, I'm looking for a best man.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'd be honored.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Sir, I'd like to request a furlough. Two days?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Granted.  Where are you going?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Cheraw Falls.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's beautiful there.  Your mother and I were there once, before you were born.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: She would have been pleased.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I'm sorry we didn't give you more warning.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's alright.  I'm very happy for you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's a good measure of a woman that she'll have her honeymoon under the stars.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: From General Clinton in New York...  "... insurgency, particularly because of the likely move south of Washington and the inevitable arrival of the French.  Militia, as you have so often pointed out, is not worth the attention of a significant army, hence it is mystifying why militia has bedeviled you for so long..."

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: "Your guardedly respectful Commander, General Sir George Clinton."

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: If I fail, you fail.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Perhaps.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: And if I triumph, you triumph.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Probably.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: How can we end this madness?

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Difficult, sir.  This is, as you pointed out, a civil war.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Civility is a secondary virtue.  It is superseded by duty.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: I understand, sir.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: I believe they are almost ready.

Speaker: gaskins
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir.  He died.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Very well, get one of the others.

Speaker: billings
Dialogue: Damn your eyes.  Do your worst.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: I intend to.

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: You still want me to give wounded Redcoats quarter?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Tarleton has a list of our men, most are on it.  A regiment of dragoons is going to the homes on the list, burning them, killing whomever resists, women and children, as well.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Seven homes along the Black River so far...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Five day furlough for all men. Abner, Dan, Reverend, spread the word.  We'll reform at Acworth.  Any man who doesn't come back won't be thought a coward or uncommitted to the cause.  Attend to your families.

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: Father!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Papa...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Susan...

Speaker: margaret
Dialogue: I told you, things would get better.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: The overlook, up there should be where you post the watch.  Work out a schedule.  Short watches, especially at night.  Now let's find someplace to cache extra weapons...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Good apple.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Very good.  Sweet.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: May I ask you a question?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Yes, of course.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Do you think Frances with an "e" is too manly a name for a girl?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Do you think Francis with an "i" is too womanly a name for a boy?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Late summer.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Congratulations.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I'm not my sister.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Excuse me?

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: I said, I'm not my sister.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I know that.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Of course, I do.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Very well, then.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Just a little goodbye?  One word? That's all I want to hear.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Goodbye, Charlotte.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Goodbye.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Papa!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Papa, don't go, I'll say anything.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Please, Papa, I'll say anything you want!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Just tell me what to say!  Tell me what to say!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Please, Papa, please don't go.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: ... I'll talk to you, I'll say anything you want, just tell me what you want me to say, I'll say anything, I promise, please, Papa, just stay...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'll come back... I promise...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: How many came back?

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: Excuse me, Ma'am, everyone has been requested to gather at the church.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: Everyone?

Speaker: redcoat sergeant
Dialogue: Colonel Tarleton wants to address, the whole village.

Speaker: redcoat
Dialogue: Into the church, please.

Speaker: another redcoat
Dialogue: Colonel Tarleton wishes to address all of you.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Open this door!

Speaker: another voice
Dialogue: By what right are we made prisoners?

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Yes, Major.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Sir, there is no honor in this.

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: The honor is found in the end, not the means.  This will be forgotten.  Proceed.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Anne...?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Don't go in there.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Is it her?  Is Anne in there?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: She is.  Don't go in there.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Father, tell me what happened at Fort Wilderness?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You know what happened.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: No, I don't.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Everyone knows.  It's what made me a hero.  Me, Harry Lee, all of us.  I got a medal.  Men bought me drinks. They still do sometimes.  Everyone knows what happened.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Tell me what everyone doesn't know.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And what do they know?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: That the French and Cherokees captured the fort and when you retook it, you took revenge on them for what they did during the occupation.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: That's not enough.  Tell me.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Your mother asked me the same question around the time you were born.  I was drunk and I was foolish enough to answer her.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: That's why it was four years between you and Thomas.  It took me that long to regain her respect.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I'm not my mother.  I can't have the respect without the knowing.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It was in '63.  It was a bad time. The French and the Cherokee had raided along the Blue Ridge.  All the English settlers took refuge at Fort Wilderness but the French captured it.  We were sent in relief.  Harry Lee, Billings, sixty of us.  We already had something of a reputation for being... harsh. When we got there the fort was abandoned.  Not a French soldier or Cherokee anywhere.  They had left a week earlier.  What we found was... bad.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: They had left the settlers there. The men had been burned alive, the women were in pieces and the children were on stakes.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We buried them, then we went to track.  It was a cold trail and they were moving fast.  We went faster. We caught up to them at Kentucky Ford.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We took our time with them and gave every one of them worse than they had given at the fort.  It was two weeks before they were all dead, all except two.  We put the heads on a pallet and had the two we let live take it to the French at Fort Ambercon.  That seemed to make a difference. The war went another year, things went better... and men bought us drinks.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It was a different time, son.  And you're a better man than that.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I see, do as I say, not as I do.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: abner
Dialogue: THEY'RE HERE!  CONTINENTALS, THEY'RE HERE!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: If this war is about more than Thomas, it's about more than Anne, as well.  Stay the course.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: As you did at Fort Wilderness?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Look at you!  I knew you could do it!

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: We have a chance!  Better than a chance!  Cornwallis is running to the Chesapeake, probably to meet his fleet at Yorktown.  I wish I could see his face when he sees a dozen French ships floating there.  And Washington should be a day or two behind him.  And on top of everything, I have a son!  Born last month in Alexandria.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: His wife was killed yesterday.  She was with child.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I didn't know.

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: Gabriel and at least a dozen others. They must have left right after the watch change.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: That means they have two hours on us.

Speaker: brother joseph
Dialogue: Fifty Green Dragoons, camped about a quarter mile from here.  Sentries at four points.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: FIRE!

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I'm alright, I...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Let me help you...

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: Colonel...

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: He looks as if he's sleeping, doesn't he?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: You have to bury him.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: I'll help you bury him.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Don't touch him.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: How many men have we seen die?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Two.  Gabriel and Thomas.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: They're gone.  And there is nothing you or I can do to bring them back. But there is something you can do to help end all this.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It is ended.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: No.  It's not over yet.  Two days ride, Yorktown, Virginia. Washington, the French, Cornwallis and Tarleton.  It will end, one way or another.  Francis, nothing will replace your sons but helping us will justify their sacrifice.

Speaker: runner
Dialogue: You called for me, sir?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Take this to General Washington.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Did you bring me this?

Speaker: runner
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Take this to Colonel Marion.

Speaker: runner
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Colonel Francis Marion.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Gray.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Earned.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Come.  I have something I want to show you.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Gentlemen.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: I was sorry to hear about your son.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I lost another a year ago, Thomas. He was only fifteen.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: I've had no sons to lose, nor daughters.  I lose the sons of other men.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Life was easier when we only had ourselves to get killed.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Gentlemen, what do we see?

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: Mortars, center, with two lines of enfilading trenches.

Speaker: pinkney
Dialogue: More along the right flank and behind the forward redoubts.

Speaker: lafayette
Dialogue: A formidable defensive position. Very formidable.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: They could hold out for weeks.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Francis, tell me about General Cornwallis.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Remember Braddock?

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: That bad?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Worse.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Proud, priggish and competent.  A very bad combination in an adversary.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: For those of you who don't know, we intercepted a British dispatch this morning.  General Clinton has sailed from New York to relieve Cornwallis.

Speaker: hamilton
Dialogue: How long before they arrive?

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: Less than a week.  Sixteen ships and over nine thousand Redcoats.

Speaker: lafayette
Dialogue: Sooner or later that message will get through to Cornwallis.

Speaker: pinkney
Dialogue: And when it does, he'll just wait us out.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: And when the British ships arrive, the French ships will flee.  And when the French ships flee, General Rochambeau and the French troops will flee as well.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Then you must let the message go through.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: If Cornwallis receives news that Clinton is coming, he'll simply hold tight and wait.  He'll fight a purely defensive battle and he'll win that.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: No, he won't.  There are two things you need to know about Cornwallis. First, he is a very proud man, He would rather risk defeat than share a victory.  If you give him what he thinks is an out, he'll take it.

Speaker: washington
Dialogue: And what is the second thing?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I'll let him tell you himself...  "... but it is this colonial militia that is the most irksome.  Not worthy of my attention, but demanding it; not worthy of British blood, but taking it; and not worthy of a soldier's honor, but sullying it.  Those nights of mine that are not sleepless, are filled with dreams of a cavalry charge on the heels of fleeing farmers..."

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: He has no respect for citizen soldiers.  That's your bait... militia.

Speaker: major halbert
Dialogue: Sir, a dispatch from General Clinton made it through the rebel lines.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Call a general staff meeting.

Speaker: aide
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: The British army believes in officers.  I believe in soldiers. After we engage, there will be no more orders.  Every man here must know what I'm about to tell you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: We are the bait in a trap.  We're militia.  Cornwallis thinks we're rabble, nothing more than a bunch of undisciplined farmers.  And if he thinks that's what we are, that's what we're going to give him. Listen up.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Do you see that, Colonel?

Speaker: tarleton
Dialogue: Unless I'm dreaming, I think I see irregulars at their center.

Speaker: cornwallis
Dialogue: Fix bayonets... dispatch the Green Dragoons.

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: COLONEL!  OUR LINE!

Speaker: dalton
Dialogue: OUR LINE IS FALTERING...

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Goodbye, Francis.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Goodbye, Harry.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And congratulations on the birth of your son.

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Thank you.  Maybe all of this will buy him some peace.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I hope so.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Your son, what did you name him?

Speaker: lee
Dialogue: Robert.  Robert E. Lee.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: A good name for a farmer.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Two pounds, fourteen ounces.

Speaker: charlotte
Dialogue: Lovely.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Wait for me...
